    Photoactive Bifunctional Degraders: Precision Tools To Regulate Protein Stability

    Miniperspective

    • Cyrille S. Kounde
      Cyrille S. Kounde

    Abstract

    Targeted protein degradation with bifunctional degraders is positioned as a remarkable game-changing strategy to control cellular protein levels and promises a new therapeutic modality in drug discovery. Light activation of a degrader to achieve exquisite spatiotemporal control over protein stability in cells has attracted the interest of multiple research groups, with recent reports demonstrating optical control of proteolysis with chimeric molecules bearing photolabile or photoswitchable motifs. In this context of targeted proteolysis research spurring the emergence of innovative tools, we examine the design, synthesis, and properties of light-activated degraders. The significant impact of this approach in regulating disease-relevant protein levels in a light-dependent manner is highlighted with key examples, and future developments to fully harness the potential of light-induced protein degradation with photoactive bifunctional molecules are discussed.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Protein expression levels within a cell are regulated by both pre- and post-translational mechanisms which maintain a fine balance between protein synthesis and protein degradation.(1) The ubiquitin–proteasome system (UPS), a key regulator of this balance, operates by tagging proteins with a polyubiquitin chain marking them for destruction at the proteasome.(2) Due to its involvement in several cellular processes such as cell cycle control, DNA repair, gene transcription, and apoptosis, dysregulation of the UPS is associated with multiple human pathologies including neurodegenerative diseases and cancers,(3) and pharmacological modulation of the UPS has been pursued extensively in drug discovery.(4)
    In the past decade, targeted protein degradation (TPD) has emerged as an innovative approach to exploit the central ubiquitin-tagging mechanism of the UPS to deplete intracellular protein levels.(5) TPD relies on the ability of molecular glues or heterobifunctional molecules to bring a target protein and an E3 ligase into close proximity in a ternary complex, leading to small molecule-directed ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation of the target protein.(6,7) While molecular glues are single agents for which the mode of action involves a conformational change of the E3 ligase resulting in the recruitment of neosubstrates,(8) bifunctional molecules require two distinct ligands joined together by a linker, whereby the first ligand binds to the target protein and the second ligand recruits the E3 ubiquitin ligase (Figure 1A). Because of their double-headed chemical structure, these compounds were first named proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs).(9) They are now established as powerful tools to regulate intracellular protein levels, and the first two PROTACs targeting the androgen receptor (ARV-110) and the estrogen receptor (ARV-471) recently entered clinical investigation for the treatment of metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer and breast cancer, respectively.(10)
    The simplicity and versatility of small molecule TPD over biological strategies (e.g., genetic or RNAi protein silencing) have attracted the interest of chemical biologists and drug discovery scientists alike.(13,14) Key benefits of PROTAC-mediated proteolysis include action at the protein level independent of regulation at the RNA level,(15) a reversible and catalytic mode of action,(16) an enhanced pharmacodynamic effect linked to the removal of all functions of the target including scaffolding capabilities,(17,18) and the opportunity to degrade proteins lacking a classical ligand binding or enzyme active site.(19,20) The latest research efforts around bifunctional degraders have mainly been directed toward expansion of the substrate scope and have provided novel degrading tools for a wide variety of biological targets.(21) Likewise, ternary complex formation has been investigated in an attempt to identify rules that will better guide PROTAC design and optimization.(22,23)
    In view of the great opportunity that TPD offers in controlling protein abundance, we and others have envisioned to expand the breadth of PROTAC applications by turning them into light-activated precision tools. Since biological processes regulated by proteins in living organisms are temporally and spatially defined, harnessing light as a tool which also operates in time and space has become a reliable strategy to achieve precise control over many cellular functions.(24) In the case of bifunctional degraders, light would allow the noninvasive spatiotemporal control of proteolysis, greatly refining the study of protein degradation. Furthermore, with degraders now progressing into the clinic, it may become important to develop strategies to address their potential on- and off-target liabilities.(25) Tissue-selective delivery of PROTACs has been reported by conjugation to antibodies,(26,27) and similarly the local application of light to deplete a disease-relevant protein in a tumor or other organ while sparing healthy tissue could improve PROTAC selectivity in vivo and reduce potential toxicity.
    Light-induced proteolysis was first explored using optogenetic methods(28,29) and was later accomplished with small molecules in genetically modified mammalian cells, as reported by Delacour et al. in 2015.(30) The authors developed a photoactivatable version of the plant hormone auxin whichpromoted the degradation of an expressed target protein fused to an auxin-inducible degron (AID) sequence. Upon irradiation, the released auxin engaged the AID and recruited an E3 ligase for polyubiquitination and final proteasomal lysis of the fused construct. Although conditional degradation with light was achieved, the system required heterologous expression of a plant-derived protein in a mammalian cell to generate an artificial E3 ligase complex. In contrast, several recent reports have described light-induced protein degradation in mammalian cells without engineering the UPS system, by means of bifunctional degraders bearing photolabile or photoswitchable groups.(31−37) Combining the attributes of light and PROTAC degradation has delivered promising results which have been highlighted in concurrent reports.(38,39) In this Miniperspective, we carefully review the design, properties, and applications of these novel precision tools as well as the associated challenges and photopharmacology prospects they bring to the table.
    While photoactive bifunctional degraders have been given diverse names and acronyms in the literature, the general terms “caged degrader” or “caged PROTAC” and “(photo)switchable [degrader/PROTAC]” will be used in this report for consistency and clarity.

    2. Caged Degraders: Irreversible Activation

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The first strategy investigated to control PROTAC activity with light uses a photosensitive appendage on one side of the bifunctional molecule to generate an inactive degrader (Figure 1A). Upon irradiation with UV light, an active degrader is irreversibly released to trigger the disposal of the studied protein. To qualify as suitable chemical tools for biological investigation, the designed caged molecules should be cell permeable, primarily inert as degraders, and stable intracellularly before photolysis. Moreover, release of the active degrader should occur in high yield after a minimal irradiation time.(40)

    2.1. Caging the Chimera: Heads or Tails?

    The caged PROTACs reviewed here consist of a ligand for a specific target connected to one of the two most frequently used E3 ligase binders for cereblon (CRBN) or von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) (Figure 1B). Since the binding modes of these E3 ligands for the respective ubiquitin ligase are well understood, notably through the −NH of the glutarimide group of thalidomide(11) and the hydroxyl group of the VHL ligand,(12) chemical functionalization with caging groups was mostly conducted on the E3 ligase recruiting part of the PROTAC (Figure 2).(31−34)
    This design relies on the ability of the caged moiety to prevent crucial binding interactions with the corresponding E3 ligase, thus precluding formation of the key ternary complex needed for ubiquitin transfer. Compounds 2–8 (Figure 2) demonstrated the versatility of the approach, and the range of targets degraded by these molecules following uncaging suggests that caging the E3 binder may deliver optical control of degradation for any functional PROTAC. However, such caged PROTACs may still interact with the target of interest via their warhead and may display activity in a binding, biochemical, or cellular assay (vide infra). A caged degrader with attenuated or abolished pharmacological activity may be more advantageous, as it may leave the biological system unperturbed prior to irradiation. However, since degradation of a target protein often induces a greater pharmacodynamic response than its inhibition,(41) a caged degrader with fully retained inhibitory activity against its target still represents a useful chemical tool provided its basal activity prior to irradiation is known or evaluated concurrently.
    A second approach to generate a photoactivatable PROTAC is to install the caging group on the target-binding moiety of the degrader, in which case, ternary complex formation is impeded due to lack of target engagement (Figure 1A). The only reported example of this kind is caged molecule 1 which showed more than 100-fold loss in binding affinity against its target bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) compared to parent inhibitor JQ1.(31) Unlike the first approach, this design leaves the E3 ligase recruiter of the PROTAC accessible and compound 1 bears a thalidomide ligand that can interact with the E3 ligase cereblon.
    With regard to E3 ligase-mediated off-target effects due to PROTAC binding, Winter et al. have shown that the uncaged PROTAC for compound 1, dBET1, recruits cereblon for degradation of BRD2–4 without inducing knockdown of the nuclear factor IKZF3.(42) Although cereblon-induced effects were not expected for caged PROTAC 1, it is important to note that modulation of the E3 ligase partner can sometimes lead to unintentional degradation of novel protein substrates as demonstrated by the work of the Winter lab on phthalimide-based degraders.(43) In contrast, indirect modulation of secondary proteins with VHL E3 ligase recruiting PROTACs has not been reported to date, and direct interference with VHL HIF binding or hypoxia regulation generally requires compound concentrations far in excess of those required for degradation by a PROTAC.(44)
    Considering the importance of the linker in PROTAC mode of action,(45) a final option to generate a caged degrader would be to insert the photolabile group on the linker itself (Figure 1A), particularly if chemical functionalization is impractical on the ligands of the degrader. Such an approach would rely on an unfavorable conformation adopted by the caged linker via steric or stereoelectronic effects to adversely impact ternary complex formation and could be enabled by structural data defining the linker orientation within the ternary complex formed by the parent PROTAC. Otherwise, the challenges of iterating caged linkers to identify a suitable inactive caged degrader suggest that functionalizing the warhead or the E3 ligase ligand with a caging group remains the most practical approach to obtain a caged PROTAC.

    2.2. Caging Chemistry and Photocleavage

    With most caged PROTACs bearing the photoactivatable group on the E3 ligase recruiting moiety, successful synthesis of the caged molecule is dependent on the chemistry that can be performed on the E3 ligase ligand. With the exception of compound 4, all reported caged degraders incorporated a 6-nitroveratryl derived group, also known as 4,5-dimethoxy-2-nitrobenzyl cage (DMNB) (Figure 2). DMNB is a frequently used photoprotecting group that can be activated using UV light with a maximum absorption at 365 nm (46) and has been installed as a carbamate (compounds 2, 3, 6, and 7), an ether (compounds 5 and 8), or a N-alkylated functionality (compound 1). All final molecules were reported as stable intracellularly before irradiation as assessed by Western blots.
    While thalidomide and its derivatives could be efficiently alkylated on their imide portion (Figure 3, caged PROTAC 5), acylation to obtain a carbamate usually required a strong base and was achieved in moderate yields (Figure 3, caged PROTACs 2, 6, 7). Late stage chemistry was also attempted to insert the DMNB group directly on the parent PROTAC of 3, but it delivered the caged molecule in low yield. A final caging step is advantageous, since in theory, a small library of PROTACs could be turned into a set of caged degraders readily, provided the warhead for the POI does not interfere with the chemistry to be performed on the E3 ligand moiety. Comparable to the DMNB group, the diethylamino coumarin (DEACM) of 4 could be activated at 365 nm and also at the longer 405 nm wavelength.(32)
    The photouncaging properties of the final molecules were evaluated in solution before initiating cell work. Upon irradiation for less than 180 s, greater than 50% uncaged material was observed in solution for most compounds (caged PROTACs 1, 3, 4, 5, and 8). Interestingly, compound 2 failed to release any significant amount of active PROTAC after irradiation for 10 min in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) solution and was eventually not tested in cells. On the contrary, compound 6 which was made from the same precursor PROTAC as 2 (dBET1) and carried an identical caging group underwent photolysis to release the active degrader, although a prolonged irradiation time was required to reach significant uncaging in solution (t1/2 = 58 min, reported time to get 50% uncaging from a 1 mM solution of 6 as measured by UV–vis). High efficiency in releasing the parent molecule upon irradiation (i.e., good quantum yield) is often a desired feature of a photocage; however, the catalytic mode of action of PROTACs may compensate for this limitation. Despite much slower cleavage kinetics than other caged PROTACs, compounds 6 and 7 did degrade their respective target upon irradiation and within a concentration range close to their parent PROTAC.
    For VHL-based caged degraders 4 and 8, the chemistry was performed on the hydroxyl group of the VHL ligand. Naro et al. synthesized a DEACM caging group before O-acylating the parent PROTAC at the final stage with a reasonable yield, whereas our group used phase transfer catalysis to successfully install the DMNB group early on via O-alkylation (Figure 3).

    2.3. Caged Degraders in Action

    2.3.1. Bromodomain-Containing Protein 4 (BRD4)

    Degradation of bromodomain and extra terminal (BET) proteins with PROTACs has been explored extensively,(47) and BETs are often used as targets to validate new assays and methodologies related to targeted protein degradation. BRD4 is also an important target in oncology due to its role in regulation of several genes associated with cell proliferation and maintenance of cell cycle.(48) Therefore, controlling BRD4 stability with light-activated degraders would provide a compelling way to modulate cancer cell proliferation in a spatiotemporal manner. BRD4 degraders such as dBET1, MZ1, or ARV-825 are well-validated chemical tools with potent cellular activity(42,44,49) and have shown promising pharmacodynamic effects in preclinical mouse models.(50,51)
    The BRD4-targeting caged PROTACs reviewed here are directly or closely related to dBET1 (compounds 1, 2, 5, 6) or MZ1 (compound 8). Consistent with their fast uncaging kinetics, caged compounds 1, 5, and 8 tested at 1 μM achieved complete degradation of BRD4 in various cell lines following irradiation at 365 nm for 180 s or less. Depletion of BRD4 was generally more pronounced with longer irradiation times, and the kinetics of degradation were very similar to the parent PROTAC using equal concentrations of caged material. The observed knockdown was also confirmed to be E3 ligase- and proteasome-dependent for all compounds, and the caged PROTACs 1, 5, and 6 negatively impacted cell survival upon irradiation (up to 39% reduction in cell viability for 5). Work in our laboratory demonstrated that treatment of HeLa cells with caged PROTAC 8 had a cytostatic effect prior to irradiation (an effect attributed to BRD4 inhibition by the free JQ1 warhead) but led to strong cytotoxicity after uncaging (Figure 4A). The consistent increase in toxicity observed upon photolysis of the caged degraders was not related to irradiation alone,(34) nor did the byproduct generated during photoactivation affect BRD4 levels.(32)
    To take light-induced degradation with caged molecules one step further, Xue et al. have investigated the knockdown of BRD4 with compound 1 in a zebrafish model, a widely used species in drug discovery and developmental biology.(52) The high BRD4 expression levels during fish embryogenesis combined with the transparency of the embryos allowed the authors to look at light-induced phenotypes originating from BRD4 depletion (Figure 4B and Figure 4C). While nonirradiated embryos treated with 1 developed a full yolk per the DMSO control, embryos irradiated at 365 nm for 10 min fail to grow a yolk extension in the presence of 1, analogous to treatment with dBET1.
    This result represents the first use of light-activated degraders in a complex multicellular organism and further highlights the important distinction between the pharmacological consequences of inhibition versus degradation.

    2.3.2. Estrogen-Related Receptor α (ERRα)

    In addition to BRD4, Naro et al. applied the photocaging strategy to a PROTAC targeting estrogen-related receptor α (ERRα), an orphan receptor with roles in metabolism, homeostasis, and breast cancer.(53) The parent PROTAC of 4 was reported by Bondeson et al. in 2015 and achieved significant reduction of ERRα receptor levels both in MCF-7 cells and in mice.(16) The caged degrader 4 was unable to degrade ERRα in the same cell line until it was uncaged by UV light. The relevance of the approach was also highlighted by triggering estrogen receptor α (ERα)-dependent transcription (normally repressed in the presence of ERRα) in MCF-7 cells transfected with a luciferase reporter gene. ERα-mediated transcription (monitored via the luciferase signal) was triggered by degradation of ERRα, which was in turn initiated upon uncaging of 4.

    2.3.3. Bruton Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) and Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase (ALK)

    Unsurprisingly, given their attractiveness as therapeutic targets in cancer, several kinases have been targeted successfully with PROTACs. This includes cyclic dependent kinases (CDKs),(54) focal-adhesion kinase (FAK),(55) TANK-binding kinase (TBK),(56) and receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs).(17) Caged PROTAC 3, which is derived from MT-802, a potent Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) degrader developed by the Crews lab,(57) substantially decreased BTK levels in a dose-dependent manner only following irradiation at 365 nm. Likewise, 7 was designed by caging the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) degrader MS4078.(58) Photoirradiation of 7 strongly reduced cellular levels of oncogenic active ALK fusion proteins, EML4-ALK and NPM-ALK, in NCI-H2228 lung cancer cells and SU-DHL-1 lymphoma cells, respectively. To achieve an antiproliferative effect to the same extent as MS4078 on SU-DHL-1 cells, caged PROTAC 7 required activation by UV light.

    3. Photoswitchable Degraders: Reversible Activation

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The examples above clearly demonstrate the potential of caged degraders as chemical tools to trigger target protein knockdown with timely precision. However, the caging strategy activates proteolysis in an irreversible manner, without the possibility to switch off the degradation event. Conversely, being able to trigger and halt protein degradation on demand would provide a subtle way to control cellular protein levels and associated biological functions. Astute structural modifications of bifunctional degraders with photoswitchable motifs have been devised to accomplish such reversible control.

    3.1. Photoswitch Design: Azobenzene at the Forefront

    Using geometrical isomerism to reversibly control biological processes has been exemplified extensively with azobenzene photoswitches,(24) and their chemical tractability and tunable properties also make them an appropriate choice for photoswitchable PROTACs.(59) It was hypothesized that incorporation of an azobenzene motif into a bifunctional molecule would allow for major changes in binary and ternary binding interactions to take place upon irradiation due to cis/trans isomerism. This change in configuration would then translate into a distinct degradation profile for each isomer (Figure 5A). As a consequence, turning proteolysis on or off would be feasible with a single molecule, simply by switching between the two geometrical isomers.
    As previously mentioned, the linker that connects the two ligands of a PROTAC plays a critical role in a degrader’s efficacy.(13) Parameters such as composition and length of the linker can have a profound impact on a degrader’s physicochemical properties as well as its conformation.(60) Taking this into account, the Carreira and Jian labs engineered the azobenzene switch as a central linker positioned between the E3 ligand and the warhead against the target protein (Figure 5B and Figure 5D, compounds 9 and 11).(35,37) Moreover, in their search for a bistable PROTAC which does not require continuous irradiation (i.e., thermodynamically stable as a trans isomer with a long cis thermal half-life), the Carreira lab incorporated into compound 9 an ortho-F4-azobenzene motif reported to possess prolonged half-life.(61) Bistable cis/trans isomers may prove beneficial to outcompete fast protein resynthesis (i.e., in the case of proteins with a high turnover), as higher concentrations of the desired isomer would be maintained without light stimulation contrary to fast relaxing switches.
    In parallel, the Trauner lab investigated multiple positions for the azobenzene group, and their most promising molecule adapted the phenyl ring of the E3 ligase ligand lenalidomide as an integral part of the photoswitch (Figure 5C, compound 10).(36) Synthesis of the highlighted tool compounds 9–11 was mainly achieved via conventional azo coupling to obtain the photoswitch followed by additional amide bond formation steps to reach several final molecules in a modular fashion. Key characteristics pertaining to those compounds are summarized in Table 1 and underscore the diversity in optical properties and degradation profiles that can be obtained using an azobenzene photoswitch.
    Table 1. Diverse Characteristics and Degradation Profiles (cis vs trans) of Photoswitchable Degraders 9, 10, and 11a

    Overall, the thermodynamically more stable trans isomer could be switched to its cis counterpart using UV or visible light and conversion was achieved with satisfactory to excellent photostationary state (PSS) ratios (68% cis for 9, above 90% cis for 10). Compound 9 was reported as bistable since thermal back isomerization from cis to trans was not observed after incubation at 37 °C for several days in solution. Although reasonable cis thermal half-lives were obtained for 10 and 11 (8.8 and 10.3 h, respectively), the active cis isomer of 10 was mainly tested under continuous pulse irradiation to maximize the intracellular concentration of the active isomer over time. Apart from thermal relaxation, switching back to the trans isomer could also be realized for 9 and 10 with good PSS using another wavelength of light (Table 1). Lastly, in addition to favorable photochemical properties, these novel photoswitchable degraders demonstrated good stability after multiple irradiation cycles and could withstand glutathione without detectable reduction, suggesting a satisfactory intracellular stability.

    3.2. Taming the Chimera: On/Off Switching

    With regard to degradation activity, the azobenzene photoswitch was generally well tolerated as an atypical linker. The two isomers from compound 9, based on pan-BET degrader ARV-771,(62) displayed a different degradation profile toward BRD2 (trans active, cis inactive) while leaving BRD4 unaffected (Figure 5B). This selectivity toward BRD2 was partly attributed to the unusual inverse amide bond connecting JQ1 to the ortho-F4-azobenzene moiety. In contrast, compound 10 showed an opposite activity profile with the cis isomer able to degrade BRD3, BRD4, and to a lesser extent BRD2, whereas the trans isomer was completely inactive toward all BRDs (Figure 5C). With the photoswitch embedded in the E3 ligase ligand, considerable changes in binary interactions (with cereblon E3 ligase) but also in ternary complex formation would be expected upon isomerization of 10 and presumably lead to this distinctive degradation outcome. As for compound 11, its trans isomer degraded BCR-ABL fusion protein and ABL while its cis isomer did not affect the levels of those proteins (Figure 5D). It is worth noting that although the pairs of isomers of 9, 10, and 11 showed remarkably unique degradation profiles between cis and trans, many of the related compounds synthesized in the course of those studies did not exhibit a clearly differentiated effect. The extensive investigation from Trauner’s lab which reported a total of 19 photoswitchable degraders including 6 targeting the prolyl cis-trans isomerase FKBP12 suggests that linker length is one critical factor among several influencing the activity profile of the two geometrical isomers (Figure 6). Taken together, those results highlight the need for additional tools to guide the design of reversible light-activated degraders and to better understand their mode of action.
    Finally, reversible initiation or arrest of proteolysis upon photoisomerization was an important proof of concept result demonstrated with compounds 9, 10, and 11. In-cell bidirectional switching was achieved using two separate wavelengths and could also be accomplished via thermal relaxation in the case of 10. This two-way on/off mechanism, which is strictly dependent on the photoswitchable PROTAC configuration, undoubtedly represents an important milestone in the spatiotemporal control of protein stability with a small molecule. To further illustrate the benefit of this approach, the effect of photoswitchable degrader 10 on cell viability was correlated with degradation of BRDs by the cis isomer. 10 was 7 times more toxic when irradiated at 390 nm (cis isomer) than when incubated in the dark (trans isomer).

    4. Summary and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Bifunctional degraders can be engineered into light-activated chemical tools with photocaging or photoswitchable functionalities, providing a compelling method for the spatiotemporal control of protein stability. Inherently, caged degraders can only switch on proteolysis via a relatively fast uncaging mechanism, mainly triggered by UV light and which generates a byproduct. As for photoswitchable degraders, their azobenzene motif allows isomerization within the visible wavelength range and offers a bidirectional on/off handle with a superior level of control, even though they may not deliver quantitative switching. Indeed, residual activity from small quantities of active isomer present in the PSS may compromise the pharmacological applications of switchable PROTACs and the stringency of switching required is likely to depend on the specific application. Furthermore, we note that PROTACs already present difficult profiles for oral delivery and balancing the physicochemical properties of two PROTAC isomers may present additional challenges of optimization.
    Although bistable switchable degraders (such as compound 9) avoid the need for continuous irradiation, fast relaxing switches may find useful applications, particularly if sustained degradation can be attained after transient generation of the bioactive cis isomer and on- or off-target toxicities minimized by subsequent fast inactivation. A tight-binding PROTAC could be retained by its target proteins for a prolonged period in the cell, and thermal reversion may assist in taming extended pharmacodynamics. Decisions on optimal half-lives needed for the active isomer may ultimately depend on the target protein and specific applications pursued, and it remains unclear whether this automatic “switch off” characteristic would offer any benefit over tuning half-life through inactivation by metabolism or excretion.
    We also note that caging of the E3 ligase component of a PROTAC (compounds 3–8) is straightforward and highly modular and offers a mechanistically predictable outcome in switching on degradation upon photoirradiation. In comparison, the reports to date on photoswitchable degraders reveal that incorporation of a photoswitch into a bifunctional molecule can be explorative and identification of geometrical isomers with distinct degradation potency may require multiple synthetic iterations. More importantly, explanation of the observed structure-degradation profiles (which is also target-dependent) has yet to be provided at a molecular level for photoswitchable degraders and will certainly involve a combination of biophysical and computational methods not only to understand the data a posteriori but also to guide future design.
    Selective and differential degradation of closely related proteins (i.e., proteins within a subfamily or isoforms) is another aspect worthy of investigation with photoswitchable degraders. This singular characteristic of PROTACs has mainly been described for kinase-targeting degraders,(63,64) and the data from Pfaff et al. (BRD2 selective degradation with trans isomer of 9) encourage further exploitation of this feature with a photoswitch design. Differential degradation of structurally related proteins upon configurational change of the degrader could permit more precise targeting and study of protein function.
    Equipped with the capacity to degrade proteins via a light-dependent mechanism and consequently modulate cellular functions, photoactive degraders have strong potential for development into the field of photopharmacology provided constraints associated with their physicochemical properties can be overcome.(65) The inclusion of lipophilic photolabile groups and azobenzene units into degraders place these compounds into an undesired drug property space. Despite their high molecular weight and high lipophilicity, the caged and photoswitchable PROTACs reviewed here displayed sufficient cell permeability and stability to achieve controlled intracellular protein knockdown. Nonetheless, we anticipate that the progression of such tool compounds in vivo (in animal models or in the clinic) will necessitate careful assessment and optimization of their pharmacokinetic properties while preserving their favorable photochemical features.(66)
    Finally, due to activating wavelengths within the UV–visible range, in vivo applications of photoactive PROTACs may be limited by light-induced cellular damage (if long irradiation times with UV light are needed) and poor tissue penetration of the incident light. Alongside sophisticated light-delivery methods,(67) strategies to develop photocaging groups and photoswitches activated in the red and near-infrared regions are rapidly emerging.(68) Integration of these innovations in the design of novel photoactive bifunctional degraders will allow deeper in vivo exploration and manipulation of biological pathways, ultimately enabling advances in precision medicine.

      The ubiquitin system
      Hershko, Avram; Ciechanover, Aaron
      Annual Review of Biochemistry (1998), 67 (), 425-479CODEN: ARBOAW; ISSN:0066-4154. (Annual Reviews Inc.)
      A review, with ∼298 refs. The selective degrdn. of many short-lived proteins in eukaryotic cells is carried out by the ubiquitin system. In this pathway, proteins are targeted for degrdn. by covalent ligation to ubiquitin, a highly conserved small protein. Ubiquitin-mediated degrdn. of regulatory proteins plays important roles in the control of numerous processes, including cell-cycle progression, signal transduction, transcriptional regulation, receptor down-regulation, and endocytosis. The ubiquitin system has been implicated in the immune response, development, and programmed cell death. Abnormalities in ubiquitin-mediated processes have been shown to cause pathol. conditions, including malignant transformation. In this review we discuss recent information on functions and mechanisms of the ubiquitin system. Since the selectivity of protein degrdn. is detd. mainly at the stage of ligation to ubiquitin, special attention is focused on what we know, and would like to know, about the mode of action of ubiquitin-protein ligation systems and about signals in proteins recognized by these systems.

      Intracellular protein degradation: from a vague idea thru the lysosome and the ubiquitin-proteasome system and onto human diseases and drug targeting
      Ciechanover, A.
      Cell Death and Differentiation (2005), 12 (9), 1178-1190CODEN: CDDIEK; ISSN:1350-9047. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Between the 1950s and 1980s, scientists were focusing mostly on how the genetic code is transcribed to RNA and translated to proteins, but how proteins were degraded had remained a neglected research area. With the discovery of the lysosome by Christian de Duve, it was assumed that cellular proteins were degraded within this organelle. However, several independent lines of exptl. evidence strongly suggested that intracellular proteolysis was largely non-lysosomal, but the mechanisms involved remained obscure. The discovery of the ubiquitin-proteasome system resolved the enigma. It is now recognized that degrdn. of intracellular proteins is involved in the regulation of a broad array of cellular processes, such as the cell cycle and division, regulation of transcription factors, and assurance of the cellular quality control. Not surprisingly, aberrations in the system have been implicated in the pathogenesis of human disease, such as malignancies and neurodegenerative disorders, which have subsequently led to an increasing effort to develop mechanism-based drugs.

      A review. Traditional pharmaceutical drug discovery is almost exclusively focused on directly controlling protein activity to cure diseases. Modulators of protein activity, esp. inhibitors, are developed and applied at high concn. to achieve maximal effects.       A review. Protein silencing is often employed as a means to aid investigations in protein function and is increasingly desired as a therapeutic approach.       Quantitative Live-Cell Kinetic Degradation and Mechanistic Profiling of PROTAC Mode of Action

      SPR-Measured Dissociation Kinetics of PROTAC Ternary Complexes Influence Target Degradation Rate
      Roy, Michael J.; Winkler, Sandra; Hughes, Scott J.; Whitworth, Claire; Galant, Michael; Farnaby, William; Rumpel, Klaus; Ciulli, Alessio
      ACS Chemical Biology (2019), 14 (3), 361-368CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      Bifunctional degrader mols., known as proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs), function by recruiting a target to an E3 ligase, forming a target/PROTAC/ligase ternary complex. Despite the importance of this key intermediate species, no detailed validation of a method to directly det. binding parameters for ternary complex kinetics has been reported, and it remains to be addressed whether tuning the kinetics of PROTAC ternary complexes may be an effective strategy to improve the efficiency of targeted protein degrdn. Here, we develop an SPR-based assay to quantify the stability of PROTAC-induced ternary complexes by measuring for the first time the kinetics of their formation and dissocn. in vitro using purified proteins. We benchmark our assay using four PROTACs that target the bromodomains (BDs) of bromodomain and extraterminal domain proteins Brd2, Brd3, and Brd4 to the von Hippel-Lindau E3 ligase (VHL). We reveal marked differences in ternary complex off-rates for different PROTACs that exhibit either pos. or neg. cooperativity for ternary complex formation relative to binary binding. The pos. cooperative degrader MZ1 forms comparatively stable and long-lived ternary complexes with either Brd4BD2 or Brd2BD2 and VHL. Equivalent complexes with Brd3BD2 are destabilized due to a single amino acid difference (Glu/Gly swap) present in the bromodomain. We observe that this difference in ternary complex dissociative half-life correlates to a greater initial rate of intracellular degrdn. of Brd2 and Brd4 relative to Brd3. These findings establish a novel assay to measure the kinetics of PROTAC ternary complexes and elucidate the important kinetic parameters that drive effective target degrdn.

      Reversible Spatiotemporal Control of Induced Protein Degradation by Bistable PhotoPROTACs
      Pfaff, Patrick; Samarasinghe, Kusal T. G.; Crews, Craig M.; Carreira, Erick M.
      ACS Central Science (2019), 5 (10), 1682-1690CODEN: ACSCII; ISSN:2374-7951. (American Chemical Society)
      Off-tissue effects are persistent issues of modern inhibition-based therapies. By merging the strategies of photopharmacol. and small-mol. degraders, we introduce a novel concept for persistent spatiotemporal control of induced protein degrdn. that potentially prevents off-tissue toxicity. Building on the successful principle of bifunctional all-small-mol. Proteolysis Targeting Chimeras (PROTACs), we designed photoswitchable PROTACs (photoPROTACs) by including ortho-F4-azobenzene linkers between both warhead ligands. This highly bistable yet photoswitchable structural component leads to reversible control over the topol. distance between both ligands. The azo-cis-isomer is obsd. to be inactive because the distance defined by the linker is prohibitively short to permit complex formation between the protein binding partners. By contrast, the azo-trans-isomer is active since it can engage both protein partners to form the necessary and productive ternary complex. Importantly, due to the bistable nature of the ortho-F4-azobenzene moiety employed, the photostationary state of the photoPROTAC is persistent, with no need for continuous irradn. This technique offers reversible on/off switching of protein degrdn. that is compatible with an intracellular environment and, therefore, could be useful in exptl. exploration of biol. signaling pathways-such as those crucial for oncogenic signal transduction. Addnl., this strategy may be suitable for therapeutic intervention to address a variety of diseases. By enabling reversible activation and deactivation of protein degrdn., photoPROTACs offer advantages over conventional photocaging strategies that irreversibly release active agents.

      Controlling PROTACs with Light
      Verma, Shreya; Manna, Debasish
      ChemMedChem (2020), 15 (14), 1258-1261CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Proteolysis targeting chimeras, PROTACs, are emerging as a powerful strategy for exerting exogenous control over protein levels, allowing small mols. to exploit the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway for targeted protein degrdn. This highlight focuses on the fusion of photochem. with these bifunctional compds., which has provided a novel pathway for spatiotemporally tuning the activation of PROTACs in the form of their photocaged and photoswitchable versions. Photocaged PROTACs consist of a hindered optolabile group that detaches only upon irradn. at a specific wavelength, releasing the active PROTAC. These modified PROTACs are inactive in the dark. Photoswitchable PROTACs are photoisomerizable mols. with azobenzene linkages that are active in either the cis or trans form and inactive in the other. The isomers interconvert upon irradn. with an appropriate wavelength of light and relax to the thermodynamically stable isomer in the dark or with another wavelength of light. Although photocaged PROTACs only permit activation control for protein degrdn., photoswitching PROTACs offer reversible activation and deactivation by using suitable wavelengths of light.

      Small-molecule PROTAC degraders of the Bromodomain and Extra Terminal (BET) proteins - A review
      Yang Chao-Yie; Qin Chong; Bai Longchuan; Wang Shaomeng
      Drug discovery today. Technologies (2019), 31 (), 43-51 ISSN:.
      The PROteolysis TArgeting Chimeric (PROTAC) concept has provided an opportunity for the discovery and development of a completely new type of therapy involving induction of protein degradation. The BET proteins, comprised of BRD2, BRD3, BRD4 and the testis-specific BRDT protein, are epigenetic readers and master transcription coactivators. Extremely potent and efficacious small-molecule PROTAC degraders of the BET proteins, based on available, potent and selective BET inhibitors, have been reported. BET degraders differ from BET inhibitors in their cellular potency, phenotypic effects, pharmacokinetic properties and toxicity profiles. Herein, we provide a review of BET degraders and the differential outcome observed in the cellular and animal models for BET degraders in comparison to BET inhibitors.

      RNAi screen identifies Brd4 as a therapeutic target in acute myeloid leukaemia
      Zuber, Johannes; Shi, Junwei; Wang, Eric; Rappaport, Amy R.; Herrmann, Harald; Sison, Edward A.; Magoon, Daniel; Qi, Jun; Blatt, Katharina; Wunderlich, Mark; Taylor, Meredith J.; Johns, Christopher; Chicas, Agustin; Mulloy, James C.; Kogan, Scott C.; Brown, Patrick; Valent, Peter; Bradner, James E.; Lowe, Scott W.; Vakoc, Christopher R.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2011), 478 (7370), 524-528CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Epigenetic pathways can regulate gene expression by controlling and interpreting chromatin modifications. Cancer cells are characterized by altered epigenetic landscapes, and commonly exploit the chromatin regulatory machinery to enforce oncogenic gene expression programs. Although chromatin alterations are, in principle, reversible and often amenable to drug intervention, the promise of targeting such pathways therapeutically has been limited by an incomplete understanding of cancer-specific dependencies on epigenetic regulators. Here the authors describe a non-biased approach to probe epigenetic vulnerabilities in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), an aggressive hematopoietic malignancy that is often assocd. with aberrant chromatin states. By screening a custom library of small hairpin RNAs (shRNAs) targeting known chromatin regulators in a genetically defined AML mouse model, the authors identify the protein bromodomain-contg. 4 (Brd4) as being critically required for disease maintenance. Suppression of Brd4 using shRNAs or the small-mol. inhibitor JQ1 led to robust antileukemic effects in vitro and in vivo, accompanied by terminal myeloid differentiation and elimination of leukemia stem cells. Similar sensitivities were obsd. in a variety of human AML cell lines and primary patient samples, revealing that JQ1 has broad activity in diverse AML subtypes. The effects of Brd4 suppression are, at least in part, due to its role in sustaining Myc expression to promote aberrant self-renewal, which implicates JQ1 as a pharmacol. means to suppress MYC in cancer. The authors' results establish small-mol. inhibition of Brd4 as a promising therapeutic strategy in AML and, potentially, other cancers, and highlight the utility of RNA interference (RNAi) screening for revealing epigenetic vulnerabilities that can be exploited for direct pharmacol. intervention.

      Hijacking the E3 Ubiquitin Ligase Cereblon to Efficiently Target BRD4
      Lu, Jing; Qian, Yimin; Altieri, Martha; Dong, Hanqing; Wang, Jing; Raina, Kanak; Hines, John; Winkler, James D.; Crew, Andrew P.; Coleman, Kevin; Crews, Craig M.
      Chemistry & Biology (Oxford, United Kingdom) (2015), 22 (6), 755-763CODEN: CBOLE2; ISSN:1074-5521. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      BRD4, a bromodomain and extraterminal domain (BET) family member, is an attractive target in multiple pathol. settings, particularly cancer. While BRD4 inhibitors have shown some promise in MYC-driven malignancies such as Burkitt's lymphoma (BL), we show that BRD4 inhibitors lead to robust BRD4 protein accumulation, which may account for their limited suppression of MYC expression, modest antiproliferative activity, and lack of apoptotic induction. Our findings provide strong evidence that cereblon-based PROTACs provide a better and more efficient strategy in targeting BRD4 than traditional small-mol. inhibitors.

      Activity of BET-proteolysis targeting chimeric (PROTAC) compounds in triple negative breast cancer
      Noblejas-Lopez Maria Del Mar; Nieto-Jimenez Cristina; Burgos Miguel; Gomez-Juarez Monica; Ocana Alberto; Noblejas-Lopez Maria Del Mar; Nieto-Jimenez Cristina; Galan-Moya Eva M; Ocana Alberto; Montero Juan Carlos; Esparis-Ogando Azucena; Pandiella Atanasio; Montero Juan Carlos; Esparis-Ogando Azucena; Pandiella Atanasio; Montero Juan Carlos; Esparis-Ogando Azucena; Pandiella Atanasio; Pandiella Atanasio; Ocana Alberto
      Journal of experimental & clinical cancer research : CR (2019), 38 (1), 383 ISSN:.
      BACKGROUND: Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an incurable disease where novel therapeutic strategies are needed. Proteolysis targeting chimeric (PROTAC) are novel compounds that promote protein degradation by binding to an ubiquitin ligase. In this work, we explored the antitumoral activity of two novel BET-PROTACs, MZ1 and ARV-825, in TNBC, ovarian cancer and in a BET inhibitor resistant model. METHODS: OVCAR3, SKOV3, BT549, MDA-MB-231 cell lines and the JQ1 resistant cell line MDA-MB-231R were evaluated. MTTs, colony-forming assay, three-dimensional cultures in matrigel, flow cytometry, and western blots were performed to explore the anti-proliferative effect and biochemical mechanism of action of MZ1 and ARV-825. In vivo studies included BALB/c nu/nu mice engrafted with MDA-MB-231R cells. RESULTS: The BET-PROTACs MZ1 and ARV-825 efficiently downregulated the protein expression levels of the BET protein BRD4, in MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-231R. MZ1 and ARV-825 also showed an antiproliferative effect on sensitive and resistant cells. This effect was corroborated in other triple negative (BT549) and ovarian cancer (SKOV3, OVCAR3) cell lines. MZ1 provoked G2/M arrest in MDA-MB-231. In addition, a profound effect on caspase-dependent apoptosis was observed in both sensitive and resistant cells. No synergistic activity was observed when it was combined with docetaxel, cisplatin or olaparib. Finally, in vivo administration of MZ1 rescued tumor growth in a JQ1-resistant xenograft model, reducing the expression levels of BRD4. CONCLUSIONS: Using both in vitro and in vivo approaches, we describe the profound activity of BET-PROTACs in parental and BETi-resistant TNBC models. This data provides options for further clinical development of these agents in TNBC.

      Sun, B.; Fiskus, W.; Qian, Y.; Rajapakshe, K.; Raina, K.; Coleman, K. G.; Crew, A. P.; Shen, A.; Saenz, D. T.; Mill, C. P.; Nowak, A. J.; Jain, N.; Zhang, L.; Wang, M.; Khoury, J. D.; Coarfa, C.; Crews, C. M.; Bhalla, K. N.

      Use of Zebrafish in Drug Discovery Toxicology
      Cassar, Steven; Adatto, Isaac; Freeman, Jennifer L.; Gamse, Joshua T.; Iturria, Inaki; Lawrence, Christian; Muriana, Arantza; Peterson, Randall T.; Van Cruchten, Steven; Zon, Leonard I.
      Chemical Research in Toxicology (2020), 33 (1), 95-118CODEN: CRTOEC; ISSN:0893-228X. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Unpredicted human safety events in clin. trials for new drugs are costly in terms of human health and money. The drug discovery industry attempts to minimize those events with diligent preclin. safety testing. Current std. practices are good at preventing toxic compds. from being tested in the clinic; however, false neg. preclin. toxicity results are still a reality. Continual improvement must be pursued in the preclin. realm. Higher quality therapies can be brought forward with more information about potential toxicities and assocd. mechanisms. The zebrafish model is a bridge between in vitro assays and mammalian in vivo studies. This model is powerful in its breadth of application and tractability for research. In the past two decades our understanding of disease biol. and drug toxicity has grown significantly owing to thousands of studies on this tiny vertebrate. This review summarizes challenges and strengths of the model, discusses the 3Rs value that it can deliver, highlights translatable and untranslatable biol., and brings together reports from recent studies with zebrafish focusing on new drug discovery toxicol.

      o-Fluoroazobenzenes as Readily Synthesized Photoswitches Offering Nearly Quantitative Two-Way Isomerization with Visible Light
      Bleger, David; Schwarz, Jutta; Brouwer, Albert M.; Hecht, Stefan
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (51), 20597-20600CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Azobenzene functionalized with ortho-fluorine atoms has a lower energy of the n-orbital of the Z-isomer, resulting in a sepn. of the E and Z isomers' n→π* absorption bands. Introducing para-substituents allows for further tuning of the absorption spectra of o-fluoroazobenzenes. In particular, electron-withdrawing ester groups give rise to a 50 nm sepn. of the n→π* transitions. Green and blue light can therefore be used to induce E→Z and Z→E isomerizations, resp. The o-fluoroazobenzene scaffold is readily synthesized and can be inserted into larger structures via its aryl termini. These new azobenzene derivs. can be switched in both ways with high photoconversions, and their Z-isomers display a remarkably long thermal half-life.

      PROTAC-induced BET protein degradation as a therapy for castration-resistant prostate cancer
      Raina, Kanak; Lu, Jing; Qian, Yimin; Altieri, Martha; Gordon, Deborah; Rossi, Ann Marie K.; Wang, Jing; Chen, Xin; Dong, Hanqing; Siu, Kam; Winkler, James D.; Crew, Andrew P.; Crews, Craig M.; Coleman, Kevin G.

      Prostate cancer has the second highest incidence among cancers in men worldwide and is the second leading cause of cancer deaths of men in the United States. Although androgen deprivation can initially lead to remission, the disease often progresses to castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), which is still reliant on androgen receptor (AR) signaling and is assocd. with a poor prognosis. Some success against CRPC has been achieved by drugs that target AR signaling, but secondary resistance invariably emerges, and new therapies are urgently needed. Recently, inhibitors of bromodomain and extra-terminal (BET) family proteins have shown growth-inhibitory activity in preclin. models of CRPC. Here, we demonstrate that ARV-771, a small-mol. pan-BET degrader based on proteolysis-targeting chimera (PROTAC) technol., demonstrates dramatically improved efficacy in cellular models of CRPC as compared with BET inhibition. Unlike BET inhibitors, ARV-771 results in suppression of both AR signaling and AR levels and leads to tumor regression in a CRPC mouse xenograft model. This study is, to our knowledge, the first to demonstrate efficacy with a small-mol. BET degrader in a solid-tumor malignancy and potentially represents an important therapeutic advance in the treatment of CRPC.

      Lessons in PROTAC Design from Selective Degradation with a Promiscuous Warhead
      Bondeson, Daniel P.; Smith, Blake E.; Burslem, George M.; Buhimschi, Alexandru D.; Hines, John; Jaime-Figueroa, Saul; Wang, Jing; Hamman, Brian D.; Ishchenko, Alexey; Crews, Craig M.
      Cell Chemical Biology (2018), 25 (1), 78-87.e5CODEN: CCBEBM; ISSN:2451-9448. (Cell Press)
      Inhibiting protein function selectively is a major goal of modern drug discovery. Here, we report a previously understudied benefit of small mol. proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) that recruit E3 ubiquitin ligases to target proteins for their ubiquitination and subsequent proteasome-mediated degrdn. Using promiscuous CRBN- and VHL-recruiting PROTACs that bind >50 kinases, we show that only a subset of bound targets is degraded. The basis of this selectivity relies on protein-protein interactions between the E3 ubiquitin ligase and the target protein, as illustrated by engaged proteins that are not degraded as a result of unstable ternary complexes with PROTAC-recruited E3 ligases. In contrast, weak PROTAC:target protein affinity can be stabilized by high-affinity target:PROTAC:ligase trimer interactions, leading to efficient degrdn. This study highlights design guidelines for generating potent PROTACs as well as possibilities for degrading undruggable proteins immune to traditional small-mol. inhibitors.

      Computational Design and Synthesis of a Deeply Red-Shifted and Bistable Azobenzene
      Konrad, David B.; Savasci, Goekcen; Allmendinger, Lars; Trauner, Dirk; Ochsenfeld, Christian; Ali, Ahmed M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2020), 142 (14), 6538-6547CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      We computationally dissected the electronic and geometrical influences of ortho-chlorinated azobenzenes on their photophys. properties. X-ray anal. provided the insight that trans-tetra-ortho-chloro azobenzene is conformationally flexible and thus subject to mol. motions. This allows the photoswitch to adopt a range of red-shifted geometries which account for the extended n → π* band tails. Based on our results, we designed the di-ortho-fluoro di-ortho-chloro (dfdc) azobenzene and provided computational evidence for the superiority of this substitution pattern to tetra-ortho-chloro azobenzene. Thereafter, we synthesized dfdc azobenzene by ortho-chlorination via 2-fold C-H activation and exptl. confirmed its structural and photophys. properties through UV-vis, NMR and X-ray analyses. The advantages include near-bistable isomers and an increased sepn. of the n → π* bands between the trans- and cis-conformations which allows for the generation of unusually high levels of the cis-isomer by irradn. with green/yellow light as well as red light within the biooptical window.

        Intracellular protein degradation: from a vague idea thru the lysosome and the ubiquitin-proteasome system and onto human diseases and drug targeting
        Ciechanover, A.
        Cell Death and Differentiation (2005), 12 (9), 1178-1190CODEN: CDDIEK; ISSN:1350-9047. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Between the 1950s and 1980s, scientists were focusing mostly on how the genetic code is transcribed to RNA and translated to proteins, but how proteins were degraded had remained a neglected research area. With the discovery of the lysosome by Christian de Duve, it was assumed that cellular proteins were degraded within this organelle. However, several independent lines of exptl. evidence strongly suggested that intracellular proteolysis was largely non-lysosomal, but the mechanisms involved remained obscure. The discovery of the ubiquitin-proteasome system resolved the enigma. It is now recognized that degrdn. of intracellular proteins is involved in the regulation of a broad array of cellular processes, such as the cell cycle and division, regulation of transcription factors, and assurance of the cellular quality control. Not surprisingly, aberrations in the system have been implicated in the pathogenesis of human disease, such as malignancies and neurodegenerative disorders, which have subsequently led to an increasing effort to develop mechanism-based drugs.

        A review. The drugable proteome is limited by the no. of functional binding sites that can bind small mols. and respond with a therapeutic effect. Orthosteric and allosteric modulators of enzyme function or receptor signaling are well-established mechanisms of drug action.         The novel mechanism of lenalidomide activity
        Fink, Emma C.; Ebert, Benjamin L.
        Blood (2015), 126 (21), 2366-2369CODEN: BLOOAW; ISSN:0006-4971. (American Society of Hematology)
        Lenalidomide acts by a novel drug mechanism-modulation of the substrate specificity of the CRL4CRBN E3 ubiquitin ligase. In multiple myeloma, lenalidomide induces the ubiquitination of IKZF1 and IKZF3 by CRL4CRBN. Subsequent proteasomal degrdn. of these transcription factors kills multiple myeloma cells. In the future, modulation of ubiquitin ligase function may enable us to target previously ''undruggable'' proteins.

        Sakamoto, Kathleen M.; Kim, Kyung B.; Kumagai, Akiko; Mercurio, Frank; Crews, Craig M.; Deshaies, Raymond J.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2001), 98 (15), 8554-8559CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        The intracellular levels of many proteins are regulated by ubiquitin-dependent proteolysis. We sought to artificially target a protein to the SCF complex for ubiquitination and degrdn. In the future, this approach may be useful for conditional inactivation of proteins, and for targeting disease-causing proteins for destruction.

        Fischer, Eric S.; Bohm, Kerstin; Lydeard, John R.; Yang, Haidi; Stadler, Michael B.; Cavadini, Simone; Nagel, Jane; Serluca, Fabrizio; Acker, Vincent; Lingaraju, Gondichatnahalli M.; Tichkule, Ritesh B.; Schebesta, Michael; Forrester, William C.; Schirle, Markus; Hassiepen, Ulrich; Ottl, Johannes; Hild, Marc; Beckwith, Rohan E.         In the 1950s, the drug thalidomide, administered as a sedative to pregnant women, led to the birth of thousands of children with multiple defects. Despite the teratogenicity of thalidomide and its derivs. lenalidomide and pomalidomide, these immunomodulatory drugs (IMiDs) recently emerged as effective treatments for multiple myeloma and 5q-deletion-assocd. dysplasia. IMiDs target the E3 ubiquitin ligase CUL4-RBX1-DDB1-CRBN (known as CRL4CRBN) and promote the ubiquitination of the IKAROS family transcription factors IKZF1 and IKZF3 by CRL4CRBN.         A review. Traditional pharmaceutical drug discovery is almost exclusively focused on directly controlling protein activity to cure diseases. Modulators of protein activity, esp. inhibitors, are developed and applied at high concn. to achieve maximal effects. Thereby, reduced bioavailability and off-target effects can hamper compd. efficacy. Nucleic acid-based strategies that control protein function by affecting expression have emerged as an alternative. However, metabolic stability and broad bioavailability represent development hurdles that remain to be overcome for these approaches. More recently, utilizing the cell's own protein destruction machinery for selective degrdn. of essential drivers of human disorders has opened up a new and exciting area of drug discovery. Small-mol.-induced proteolysis of selected substrates offers the potential of reaching beyond the limitations of the current pharmaceutical paradigm to expand the druggable target space.

        Advances in targeted degradation of endogenous proteins
        Roth, Sascha; Fulcher, Luke J.; Sapkota, Gopal P.
        Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences (2019), 76 (14), 2761-2777CODEN: CMLSFI; ISSN:1420-682X. (Birkhaeuser Basel)
        A review. Protein silencing is often employed as a means to aid investigations in protein function and is increasingly desired as a therapeutic approach. Several types of protein silencing methodologies have been developed, including targeting the encoding genes, transcripts, the process of translation or the protein directly. Despite these advances, most silencing systems suffer from limitations. Silencing protein expression through genetic ablation, for example by CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing, is irreversible, time consuming and not always feasible. Similarly, RNA interference approaches warrant prolonged treatments, can lead to incomplete protein depletion and are often assocd. with off-target effects. Targeted proteolysis has the potential to overcome some of these limitations. The field of targeted proteolysis has witnessed the emergence of many methodologies aimed at targeting specific proteins for degrdn. in a spatio-temporal manner. In this review, we provide an appraisal of the different targeted proteolytic systems and discuss their applications in understanding protein function, as well as their potential in therapeutics.

        Two decades into the twenty-first century, a confluence of breakthrough technologies wielded at the mol. level is presenting biologists with unique opportunities to unravel the complexities of the cellular world. CRISPR/Cas9 allows gene knock-outs, knock-ins, and single-base editing at chromosomal loci. RNA-based tools such as siRNA, antisense oligos, and morpholinos can be used to silence expression of specific genes. Meanwhile, protein knockdown tools that draw inspiration from natural regulatory mechanisms and facilitate elimination of native or degron-tagged proteins from cells are rapidly emerging. In this Review, we summarize the ingenious ways biologists have exploited natural mechanisms for protein degrdn. to direct the elimination of specific proteins at will. This has led to advancements not only in basic research but also in the therapeutic space with the introduction of PROTACs into clin. trials for cancer patients.

        Quantitative Live-Cell Kinetic Degradation and Mechanistic Profiling of PROTAC Mode of Action
        Riching, Kristin M.; Mahan, Sarah; Corona, Cesear R.; McDougall, Mark; Vasta, James D.; Robers, Matthew B.; Urh, Marjeta; Daniels, Danette L.
        ACS Chemical Biology (2018), 13 (9), 2758-2770CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)

        SPR-Measured Dissociation Kinetics of PROTAC Ternary Complexes Influence Target Degradation Rate
        Roy, Michael J.; Winkler, Sandra; Hughes, Scott J.; Whitworth, Claire; Galant, Michael; Farnaby, William; Rumpel, Klaus; Ciulli, Alessio
        ACS Chemical Biology (2019), 14 (3), 361-368CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
        Bifunctional degrader mols., known as proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs), function by recruiting a target to an E3 ligase, forming a target/PROTAC/ligase ternary complex. Despite the importance of this key intermediate species, no detailed validation of a method to directly det. binding parameters for ternary complex kinetics has been reported, and it remains to be addressed whether tuning the kinetics of PROTAC ternary complexes may be an effective strategy to improve the efficiency of targeted protein degrdn. Here, we develop an SPR-based assay to quantify the stability of PROTAC-induced ternary complexes by measuring for the first time the kinetics of their formation and dissocn. in vitro using purified proteins. We benchmark our assay using four PROTACs that target the bromodomains (BDs) of bromodomain and extraterminal domain proteins Brd2, Brd3, and Brd4 to the von Hippel-Lindau E3 ligase (VHL). We reveal marked differences in ternary complex off-rates for different PROTACs that exhibit either pos. or neg. cooperativity for ternary complex formation relative to binary binding. The pos. cooperative degrader MZ1 forms comparatively stable and long-lived ternary complexes with either Brd4BD2 or Brd2BD2 and VHL. Equivalent complexes with Brd3BD2 are destabilized due to a single amino acid difference (Glu/Gly swap) present in the bromodomain. We observe that this difference in ternary complex dissociative half-life correlates to a greater initial rate of intracellular degrdn. of Brd2 and Brd4 relative to Brd3. These findings establish a novel assay to measure the kinetics of PROTAC ternary complexes and elucidate the important kinetic parameters that drive effective target degrdn.

        Reversible Spatiotemporal Control of Induced Protein Degradation by Bistable PhotoPROTACs
        Pfaff, Patrick; Samarasinghe, Kusal T. G.; Crews, Craig M.; Carreira, Erick M.
        ACS Central Science (2019), 5 (10), 1682-1690CODEN: ACSCII; ISSN:2374-7951. (American Chemical Society)
        Off-tissue effects are persistent issues of modern inhibition-based therapies. By merging the strategies of photopharmacol. and small-mol. degraders, we introduce a novel concept for persistent spatiotemporal control of induced protein degrdn. that potentially prevents off-tissue toxicity. Building on the successful principle of bifunctional all-small-mol. Proteolysis Targeting Chimeras (PROTACs), we designed photoswitchable PROTACs (photoPROTACs) by including ortho-F4-azobenzene linkers between both warhead ligands. This highly bistable yet photoswitchable structural component leads to reversible control over the topol. distance between both ligands. The azo-cis-isomer is obsd. to be inactive because the distance defined by the linker is prohibitively short to permit complex formation between the protein binding partners. By contrast, the azo-trans-isomer is active since it can engage both protein partners to form the necessary and productive ternary complex. Importantly, due to the bistable nature of the ortho-F4-azobenzene moiety employed, the photostationary state of the photoPROTAC is persistent, with no need for continuous irradn. This technique offers reversible on/off switching of protein degrdn. that is compatible with an intracellular environment and, therefore, could be useful in exptl. exploration of biol. signaling pathways-such as those crucial for oncogenic signal transduction. Addnl., this strategy may be suitable for therapeutic intervention to address a variety of diseases.         Controlling PROTACs with Light
        Verma, Shreya; Manna, Debasish
        ChemMedChem (2020), 15 (14), 1258-1261CODEN: CHEMGX; ISSN:1860-7179. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Proteolysis targeting chimeras, PROTACs, are emerging as a powerful strategy for exerting exogenous control over protein levels, allowing small mols. to exploit the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway for targeted protein degrdn. This highlight focuses on the fusion of photochem. with these bifunctional compds., which has provided a novel pathway for spatiotemporally tuning the activation of PROTACs in the form of their photocaged and photoswitchable versions. Photocaged PROTACs consist of a hindered optolabile group that detaches only upon irradn. at a specific wavelength, releasing the active PROTAC. These modified PROTACs are inactive in the dark. Photoswitchable PROTACs are photoisomerizable mols. with azobenzene linkages that are active in either the cis or trans form and inactive in the other. The isomers interconvert upon irradn. with an appropriate wavelength of light and relax to the thermodynamically stable isomer in the dark or with another wavelength of light. Although photocaged PROTACs only permit activation control for protein degrdn., photoswitching PROTACs offer reversible activation and deactivation by using suitable wavelengths of light.

        RNAi screen identifies Brd4 as a therapeutic target in acute myeloid leukaemia
        Zuber, Johannes; Shi, Junwei; Wang, Eric; Rappaport, Amy R.; Herrmann, Harald; Sison, Edward A.; Magoon, Daniel; Qi, Jun; Blatt, Katharina; Wunderlich, Mark; Taylor, Meredith J.; Johns, Christopher; Chicas, Agustin; Mulloy, James C.; Kogan, Scott C.; Brown, Patrick; Valent, Peter; Bradner, James E.; Lowe, Scott W.; Vakoc, Christopher R.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2011), 478 (7370), 524-528CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Epigenetic pathways can regulate gene expression by controlling and interpreting chromatin modifications. Cancer cells are characterized by altered epigenetic landscapes, and commonly exploit the chromatin regulatory machinery to enforce oncogenic gene expression programs. Although chromatin alterations are, in principle, reversible and often amenable to drug intervention, the promise of targeting such pathways therapeutically has been limited by an incomplete understanding of cancer-specific dependencies on epigenetic regulators. Here the authors describe a non-biased approach to probe epigenetic vulnerabilities in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), an aggressive hematopoietic malignancy that is often assocd. with aberrant chromatin states. By screening a custom library of small hairpin RNAs (shRNAs) targeting known chromatin regulators in a genetically defined AML mouse model, the authors identify the protein bromodomain-contg. 4 (Brd4) as being critically required for disease maintenance. Suppression of Brd4 using shRNAs or the small-mol. inhibitor JQ1 led to robust antileukemic effects in vitro and in vivo, accompanied by terminal myeloid differentiation and elimination of leukemia stem cells. Similar sensitivities were obsd. in a variety of human AML cell lines and primary patient samples, revealing that JQ1 has broad activity in diverse AML subtypes. The effects of Brd4 suppression are, at least in part, due to its role in sustaining Myc expression to promote aberrant self-renewal, which implicates JQ1 as a pharmacol. means to suppress MYC in cancer. The authors' results establish small-mol. inhibition of Brd4 as a promising therapeutic strategy in AML and, potentially, other cancers, and highlight the utility of RNA interference (RNAi) screening for revealing epigenetic vulnerabilities that can be exploited for direct pharmacol. intervention.

        Activity of BET-proteolysis targeting chimeric (PROTAC) compounds in triple negative breast cancer
        Noblejas-Lopez Maria Del Mar; Nieto-Jimenez Cristina; Burgos Miguel; Gomez-Juarez Monica; Ocana Alberto; Noblejas-Lopez Maria Del Mar; Nieto-Jimenez Cristina; Galan-Moya Eva M; Ocana Alberto; Montero Juan Carlos; Esparis-Ogando Azucena; Pandiella Atanasio; Montero Juan Carlos; Esparis-Ogando Azucena; Pandiella Atanasio; Montero Juan Carlos; Esparis-Ogando Azucena; Pandiella Atanasio; Pandiella Atanasio; Ocana Alberto
        Journal of experimental & clinical cancer research : CR (2019), 38 (1), 383 ISSN:.
        BACKGROUND: Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an incurable disease where novel therapeutic strategies are needed. Proteolysis targeting chimeric (PROTAC) are novel compounds that promote protein degradation by binding to an ubiquitin ligase. In this work, we explored the antitumoral activity of two novel BET-PROTACs, MZ1 and ARV-825, in TNBC, ovarian cancer and in a BET inhibitor resistant model. METHODS: OVCAR3, SKOV3, BT549, MDA-MB-231 cell lines and the JQ1 resistant cell line MDA-MB-231R were evaluated. MTTs, colony-forming assay, three-dimensional cultures in matrigel, flow cytometry, and western blots were performed to explore the anti-proliferative effect and biochemical mechanism of action of MZ1 and ARV-825. In vivo studies included BALB/c nu/nu mice engrafted with MDA-MB-231R cells. RESULTS: The BET-PROTACs MZ1 and ARV-825 efficiently downregulated the protein expression levels of the BET protein BRD4, in MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-231R. MZ1 and ARV-825 also showed an antiproliferative effect on sensitive and resistant cells. This effect was corroborated in other triple negative (BT549) and ovarian cancer (SKOV3, OVCAR3) cell lines. MZ1 provoked G2/M arrest in MDA-MB-231. In addition, a profound effect on caspase-dependent apoptosis was observed in both sensitive and resistant cells. No synergistic activity was observed when it was combined with docetaxel, cisplatin or olaparib. Finally, in vivo administration of MZ1 rescued tumor growth in a JQ1-resistant xenograft model, reducing the expression levels of BRD4. CONCLUSIONS: Using both in vitro and in vivo approaches, we describe the profound activity of BET-PROTACs in parental and BETi-resistant TNBC models. This data provides options for further clinical development of these agents in TNBC.

        A review. Unpredicted human safety events in clin. trials for new drugs are costly in terms of human health and money.         o-Fluoroazobenzenes as Readily Synthesized Photoswitches Offering Nearly Quantitative Two-Way Isomerization with Visible Light
        Bleger, David; Schwarz, Jutta; Brouwer, Albert M.; Hecht, Stefan
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (51), 20597-20600CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Azobenzene functionalized with ortho-fluorine atoms has a lower energy of the n-orbital of the Z-isomer, resulting in a sepn. of the E and Z isomers' n→π* absorption bands. Introducing para-substituents allows for further tuning of the absorption spectra of o-fluoroazobenzenes. In particular, electron-withdrawing ester groups give rise to a 50 nm sepn. of the n→π* transitions. Green and blue light can therefore be used to induce E→Z and Z→E isomerizations, resp. The o-fluoroazobenzene scaffold is readily synthesized and can be inserted into larger structures via its aryl termini. These new azobenzene derivs. can be switched in both ways with high photoconversions, and their Z-isomers display a remarkably long thermal half-life.

        Lessons in PROTAC Design from Selective Degradation with a Promiscuous Warhead
        Bondeson, Daniel P.; Smith, Blake E.; Burslem, George M.; Buhimschi, Alexandru D.; Hines, John; Jaime-Figueroa, Saul; Wang, Jing; Hamman, Brian D.; Ishchenko, Alexey; Crews, Craig M.
        Cell Chemical Biology (2018), 25 (1), 78-87.e5CODEN: CCBEBM; ISSN:2451-9448. (Cell Press)
        Inhibiting protein function selectively is a major goal of modern drug discovery. Here, we report a previously understudied benefit of small mol. proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) that recruit E3 ubiquitin ligases to target proteins for their ubiquitination and subsequent proteasome-mediated degrdn. Using promiscuous CRBN- and VHL-recruiting PROTACs that bind >50 kinases, we show that only a subset of bound targets is degraded. The basis of this selectivity relies on protein-protein interactions between the E3 ubiquitin ligase and the target protein, as illustrated by engaged proteins that are not degraded as a result of unstable ternary complexes with PROTAC-recruited E3 ligases. In contrast, weak PROTAC:target protein affinity can be stabilized by high-affinity target:PROTAC:ligase trimer interactions, leading to efficient degrdn. This study highlights design guidelines for generating potent PROTACs as well as possibilities for degrading undruggable proteins immune to traditional small-mol. inhibitors.

        Development of targeted protein degradation therapeutics
        Chamberlain, Philip P.; Hamann, Lawrence G.
        Nature Chemical Biology (2019), 15 (10), 937-944CODEN: NCBABT; ISSN:1552-4450. (Nature Research)
        Targeted protein degrdn. as a therapeutic modality has seen dramatic progress and massive investment in recent years because of the convergence of two key scientific breakthroughs: optimization of first-generation peptidic proteolysis-targeted chimeras (PROTACs) into more drug-like mols. able to support in vivo proof of concept and the discovery that clin. mols. function as degraders by binding and repurposing the proteins cereblon and DCAF15. This provided clin. validation for the general approach through the cereblon modulator class of drugs and provided highly drug-like and ligand-efficient E3 ligase binders upon which to tether target-binding moieties. Increasingly rational and systematic approaches including biophys. and structural studies on ternary complexes are being leveraged as the field advances. In this Perspective we summarize the discoveries that have laid the foundation for future degrdn. therapeutics, focusing on those classes of small mols. that redirect E3 ubiquitin ligases to non-native substrates.

        On the Promise of Photopharmacology Using Photoswitches: A Medicinal Chemist's Perspective
        Fuchter, Matthew J.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2020), 63 (20), 11436-11447CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Photopharmacol. is a growing area of endeavor that employs photoswitchable ligands to allow for light-dependent pharmacol. activity. By coupling light to therapeutic action, improved spatial and temporal selectivity can be achieved and subsequently harnessed for new concepts in therapy. Tremendous progress has already been made, with photopharmacol. agents now reported against a wide array of target classes and light-dependent results demonstrated in a range of live cell and animal models. Several challenges remain, however, esp. in order for photopharmacol. to truly impact the clin. management of disease. This Perspective aims to summarize these challenges, particularly with attention to the medicinal chem. that will be unavoidably required for the further translation of these agents/approaches. By clearly defining challenges for drug hunters, it is hoped that further research into the medicinal chem. of photopharmacol. agents will be stimulated, ultimately enabling full realization of the huge potential for this exciting field.

        New players in phototherapy: photopharmacology and bio-integrated optoelectronics
        Morstein, Johannes; Trauner, Dirk
        Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (2019), 50 (), 145-151CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Photodynamic therapy and phototherapy are used in the clinic to treat dermatol. conditions, cancer, macular degeneration, and a variety of other diseases. Despite their long history and widespread application, the scope of these therapeutic approaches has been limited by a lack of specificity and challenges with light delivery. In recent years, much progress has been made in these regards. Photopharmacol. has provided drug-like mols. that change their efficacy upon irradn. and allow for the optical control of a wide range of defined biol. targets. Many photopharmaceuticals are now used in vivo and some show promising results in preclin. development. At the same time, new bioelectronics for subdermal light delivery have been engineered that could enable phototherapy deep in tissue, for example within the human brain. These developments could increase the impact of photodynamic therapy in human precision medicine.

        68
        Computational Design and Synthesis of a Deeply Red-Shifted and Bistable Azobenzene
        Konrad, David B.; Savasci, Goekcen; Allmendinger, Lars; Trauner, Dirk; Ochsenfeld, Christian; Ali, Ahmed M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2020), 142 (14), 6538-6547CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        We computationally dissected the electronic and geometrical influences of ortho-chlorinated azobenzenes on their photophys. properties. X-ray anal. provided the insight that trans-tetra-ortho-chloro azobenzene is conformationally flexible and thus subject to mol. motions. This allows the photoswitch to adopt a range of red-shifted geometries which account for the extended n → π* band tails. Based on our results, we designed the di-ortho-fluoro di-ortho-chloro (dfdc) azobenzene and provided computational evidence for the superiority of this substitution pattern to tetra-ortho-chloro azobenzene. Thereafter, we synthesized dfdc azobenzene by ortho-chlorination via 2-fold C-H activation and exptl. confirmed its structural and photophys. properties through UV-vis, NMR and X-ray analyses. The advantages include near-bistable isomers and an increased sepn. of the n → π* bands between the trans- and cis-conformations which allows for the generation of unusually high levels of the cis-isomer by irradn. with green/yellow light as well as red light within the biooptical window.
